Title: A more inclusive phylogeny of the Pterosauria
Abstract:
For over a hundred years pterosaurs have been divided into
basal long-tailed ‘rhamphorhynchoids’ and derived short-tailed
‘pterodactyloids’. The transition from one grade to the other was
something of a mystery until Darwinopterus was promoted as the ‘missing
link’ and upheld as a unique example of ‘modular evolution’. Here, by
including dozens of tiny pterosaurs that have been so long ignored,
along with several juveniles and embryos, plus dozens of previously
omitted congeneric specimens, a more inclusive hypothesis of pterosaur
taxonomy is presented that upsets dominating paradigms. Miniaturization
occurred several times at the genesis of new pterosaur clades. Several
anurognathids and eudimorphodontids were smaller than their descendants
and ancestors. The Early Jurassic Campylognathoides produced tiny
descendants that evolved to become larger Late Jurassic Rhamphorhynchus
specimens. A clade arising from Dorygnathus produced tiny adults with
longer necks, longer metacarpals and shorter lateral pedal digits to
become pterodactyloid-grade azhdarchids. Another clade of dorygnathids
convergently produced tiny descendants that ultimately became larger
pterodactyloid-grade ctenochasmatids. Sordes gave rise to the
Darwinopterus and Scaphognathus clades. The Scaphognathus clade reduced
to hummingbird size before producing larger pterodactyloid-grade
Cycnorhamphidae and Ornithocheiridae on one branch. Another branch gave
rise to Pterodactyloidea and Germanodactyloidea. Two branches of the
latter ultimately produced the clades Dsungaripteridae + Tapejaridae and
Pteranodontidae. Ironically, the Darwinopterus clade left no
descendants, evidently because they produced no tiny descendants. The
evolution of convergent pterodactyloid-grade traits in four pterosaur
clades can be traced back to the special niches encountered by the
fly-sized hatchlings of tiny transitional pterosaurs.
